Integers, rational numbers, real numbers, and complex number all have additive
inverses, as they contain negative as well as positive numbers. Natural numbers,
cardinal numbers, and ordinal numbers, on the other hand, do not have additive
inverses within their respective sets. Thus, for example, we can say that
natural numbers do have additive inverses, but because these additive inverses
are not themselves natural numbers, the set of natural numbers is not ''closed''
under taking additive inverses.
